Predator (the first - and only the first) is one of the greatest sci-fi movies ever made. In fact, I would go further - I would say it's one of the greatest action movies ever made. And at a current 80% on RT - it's deeply underrated.

The story is simple. A team of marines are sent into a jungle to rescue a downed chopper. But the hunters find themselves hunted by something entirely extraterretrial.

It honestly shouldn't have been the masterpiece it is. A 1980s Arnie B-movie, a duel between man and alien, set entirely in a jungle. And problems with the production abounded. The initial alien design was a disaster, and had to be replaced mid-movie. Filming on location was a horrible experience for cast and crew. But, as is often the case, somehow the worst production result in the best results.

Predator grabs you from the opening shot. Nothing is wasted. And yet, it also doesn't rush. Tension is somehow built at the perfect, goldilocks, pace. A lot of credit goes to the music - one of Alan Silvestri's best scores - militant yet awestruck, it siezes you early on and never lets go. It deservedly won all of the handful of awards the movie received. The location is also used to maximum effect - the jungle itself haunts the characters long before the monster does. Watching the behind the scenes, it is just fascinating how the crew had to 'edit' the on-set jungle - pruning leaves, even building fake trees, to make it more cinematic.

The camaraderie between the superb cast is palpable, and the military training they received on set is on full display. As for Arnold - this is one of his best performances. Not restrained and robotic like Terminator - but genuine, convincing, and above all vulnerable.

But above all, it's the structure of the story that is the real triumph here. The story lets us see how completely badass Arnold's team in one of the best shot action sequences of modern movies, before the predator begins to pick them off one by one. Watching the hunters become the hunted, raises the monster's status exponentially, and fills us as the audience with dread. If even THESE guys can't deal with this... The marines are completely outmatched by both the alien's technology and the way it uses the jungle against them. 

There is contextual subtext here - like many 80s movie, America's trauma at being outmatched by an invisible jungle foe in Vietnam is on full display. It's also interesting from a race-theory perspective that the predator (coded black with rastafarian head dress) is more easily seen by the black, native american and female members of the team, and is impossible for the white males to comprehend. This is what a literature degree does to you. The predator is also no typical mindless grizzly - it is a warrior with its own peculiar alien code and goals. A big game hunter after a challenge. Like THE alien of Ripley fame, it is a monster that has spawned many a sequel, but sadly the tantalising glimpses of culture and mythos set up here have never been satisfactoritly developed, at least not by the movies.

And the ending? No spoilers here, but the last act does not disappoint. How Arnold comes to terms with the predator is just genius, and satisfies at every level. Predator has been much criticized fro a few deliberately crass jokes (fitting for soldiers?), and is probably widely sneered at by a certain kind of critic just for being this kind of movie with this lead. Hear none of it. This is brilliant writing, design and filmmaking at every level. If you are in any way a fan of either action or sci-fi, and you haven't seen this yet - watch it NOW! Forget the far inferior recent Prey which somehow has a higher rating. Let the Predator hunt you for a couple of hours.

"Predator" stars Arnold Schwarzenegger as Dutch, the leader of a skilled mercenary commando group who have been active throughout the war zones of the World. Hired by Dillon ( Carl Weathers ), a senior U.S. military officer, to rescue survivors of a helicopter crash in the Central America jungle, Dutch and his well armed colleagues sneak into their last known location. What ensues is a high octane, gritty action battle very reminiscent of a Vietnam war film.¬†

"Predator" starts as a standard action movie full of extreme masculinity but quickly develops into something more thrilling. Once the mercenary group have cleared the area of enemies they discover the mission was more about retrieving information rather than people. This is the first red flag. As they leave the now destroyed compound and base with their spoils, the group become aware something in the jungle is hunting them. From a number of POV shots in blurry, heat seeking vision it becomes clear the hunter is obviously not human.¬†

What "Predator" purposely does is take a u turn on the Commando groups winning formula of sheer masculinity and over the top personality traits. The initial heroism, massive biceps, excessive gun fire and destruction being the success to any battle this group encounter is useless against the alien now picking them off one by one. Random destruction and excessive gun fire does not work against the well driven hunter. The tone of the movie completely changes from pure action to a sinister thriller. it's now the "Predator" that is doing the hunting and not for any other reason than just for sport. It collects skulls as trophies and has the mindset of the thrill of the hunt. This becomes evident when despite all the alien's high tech and what could of been ease of the kill, the predator throws off its armour to fight hand to hand against the almost super human Dutch. The predator is now representing excessive masculinity at its deadly worst. Strong, well built and focussed on its own strength and cunning to win the fight, the predator not only enjoys the thrill of the hunt but finding a worthy adversary to come up against.

A classic. John McTiernan's 1987 film just works. It's a great time, capturing the era which it came out in but also feeling timeless.

The story is simple, centering around a group of soldiers who go to rescue hostages in a jungle where they encounter an a Predator, a technologically advanced alien. It sounds simple, and it is. It doesn't need to be complex, because its premise is amplified by the fellowship of characters and their awesome chemistry. Arnold Schwarzenegger delivers a surprisingly strong performance, showing some flexibility in his role. 
The rest of the cast is great too, exchanging quips and remarks, but also expressing their humanity. You really care for them when they start dying. The Predator itself is menacing, like no other on-screen antagonist. 

The tones well meshed together. It ranges from cheerful, 1980s testosterone and macho men to extreme seriousness, where you genuinely don't know what's going to happen to our characters. It's tense, suspenseful and action packed, never dragging or boring the viewer.


The visuals they use to show the camouflaged Predator hold up pretty well further fuelling the tension and suspense as the heroes face a foe they can not see. The action sequences are great, featuring explosions, usage of heavy artillery as well as blood and gore. The location and cinematography are excellent, capturing the tense, claustrophobic feel of the film. It almost makes you feel as if you're there, watching everything play out. It's strange and uncomfortable. It's further helped by the excellent score from Alan Silvestri.


In conclusion, "Predator" is a must watch for all film lovers, action fans and anyone who just wants an entertaining experience. It's a macho 1980s film that's more than just a popcorn flick or stereotype. It's an awesome film and all-time great filled with iconic moments and phrases from one of the genre's best directors, John McTiernan.

Director John McTiernan, of Die Hard, Die Hard with a Vengeance, and Last Action Hero fame, directs his fearsome sci-fi horror action-thriller Predator (1987) with searing vision and innovative techniques. McTiernan's direction is brilliant as Predator pretends it's an ultra American action-thriller with guns blazing and massive explosions, while slowly hinting at an invisible danger, until we see through the Predator's heat vision and realize this is really a horror slasher. I cannot even imagine what watching Predator in a movie theater felt like back in 1987 once you realize the berserker barrage of bullets leads to guerilla warfare and survival horror with a cosmic twist. Predator is one of a kind.

I love that every single time you see the Predator, you learn something new about his alien race, otherworldly technology, or hunter tactics. I'm in awe of how many cool abilities they wrote for the Predator to contain from his heat vision helmet, red eyesight, invisible camouflage, neon green blood, voice recording for mimicry playback diversions, three red dot sight, shoulder mounted laser gun, skull trophy coveting, aiming only for the armed prey for sport, inability to see body heat once flesh is covered in mud, medical packs hidden in his armored gear, jagged dual blades from his wrist, heated blades by laser, clicking noises, silver face mask, James Cameron's idea for face mandibles that open up his mouth, self destruct failsafe, to the Predator's smart fast learning capabilities. The Predator is the ultimate efficient hunter and he remains one of horror's most iconic creatures! The Predator is like the Xenomorph from Alien, but intelligent and able to adapt to different hunting tactics.

John McTiernan's direction is truly inventive. Allowing us as the audience to see in heat vision with blurred motion like the Predator is super cool, immediately shocking, and outstandingly creative direction from McTiernan. He makes the jungle as foreboding and scary like the Predator could be hiding in any tree. Predator feels like an amalgamation of many classics like the eerie wilderness and haunting atmosphere of Apocalypse Now, the tense jungle chases and daring escapes of Deliverance, the brazen hunting of men for ruthless sport and gory bodily trophies like The Most Dangerous Game, all mixed with the lethal vicious extra-terrestrial of Alien. Gunfire upon gunfire with all manner of survival tactics at play. Predator remains gripping, scary, and intriguing as tension rises into the finale of Arnold versus the Predator ensues.

Writers Jim Thomas and John Thomas deliver fiery language, hilarious one liners, startlingly real characterization, and terrifying horror scenarios. I've already detailed how creatively they thought about the Predator's gear and abilities. Predator features one of the most efficient scripts I've ever heard. Each person just says their honest observations with a blunt realism and haunted faces. The dialogue is at a minimum, but very expressive. I like how with each Predator reveal we realize he is a clever hunter, capable of healing himself, as he carefully engages in guerilla warfare to hunt down his human prey. There's simply no more chilling horror action film.

Arnold Schwarzenegger is commanding and cool as Major Alan "Dutch" Schaefer. Dutch is as buff as Schwarzenegger has ever looked, but it is also Arnold's expressive faces of worry, shock, and determination that make Dutch such a fabulous action hero for Predator. He's a strong man, but a stronger leader with real convictions. He wants to save lives in his mercenary missions, but all to keep his crew alive as he nearly sacrifices himself for the lives of his surviving men. Arnold delivers some of his finest acting in Predator with funny one liners, haunted faces, worried lines, and all in a gritty display of masculine strength and perseverance. His thousand mile stare in the helicopter at the end of Predator looks like the PTSD dead eyed glare of real war veterans.

Carl Weathers is excellent as the shady CIA operative Al Dillon. He feels like Dutch's old friend, but also a scumbag CIA agent willing to sacrifice every man there for the mission. Weathers is as muscular and ripped as Arnold with enough muscles to move mountains and sheer charisma to captivate any viewer. I don't know who looks more jacked between Arnold's giant arms or Carl's rippled abdomen. Elpidia Carrillo is enchanting and gripping as the lovely insurgent Anna Gonsalves. Her looks of being scared and nervous are chilling. I love how diverse Predator's cast is too by the way.

Bill Duke is purely adrenaline as the gripping machine gunner Sergeant Mac Eliot. His blindfire machine gunning into the woods once he sees the Predator is actually terrifying. Duke plays a man completely hypnotized by fear and revenge. Richard Chaves is funny as explosives expert Jorge "Poncho" Ram√≠rez with his rapid fire grenade launcher for explosive scenes. Jesse Ventura basically plays himself as the embodiment of toxic male attributes heavy gunner Blain Cooper with his brutal minigun "Ol' Painless." His soaring gunfire is as loud as the gun blasts in Heat. Sonny Landham is fascinating as the Native American tracker and scout Billy Sole. You can tell he's aware there's something in the woods. His stares into the distance are eerie. Shane Black is hilarious because he's not funny as the wise cracking radio operator Rick Hawkins. I have to mention the massive Kevin Peter Hall as the Predator. He's terrifying and expressive without any real dialogue.

Cinematographer Donald McAlpine shoots beautiful establishing wide shots of the forestry. His lush greens and woodsy browns with moodily lit shots create a real eerie atmosphere for Predator. The fast sweeping panning shots for running and slow shots of the Predator's vision are haunting unto themselves. You're always searching the woodland environment for any hint or sign of the Predator until you glimpse his invisible camouflage moving in a blur. I like how the camera perspective changes from person to Predator. You always feel his eyes watching the mercenary group. I love McAlpine's striking close-ups of fear or hesitation. Editors Mark Helfrich and John F. Link's cuts from perspectives gives the viewer every angle of the jungle to really scan each frame for the Predator.

John Vallone's production design features jungle military bases and crafty forest hunting traps. I love all the props from the Predator's knives to the mini gatling gun Ventura sports. Predator's art direction from Jorge Sainz, Theresa Wachter, and Frank Richwood is stunning with lovely jungle trees and leaves everywhere and dingy mud covering the Earth. Predator focuses on the trees to really drive home that the Predator could be hiding amongst any of the natural environment. Set decoration from Enrique Est√©vez and Macedonio Ramos put CIA secrets, ammunitions, and guns littered all over besides extra twigs and tree branches.

I adore the practical Predator costume. The visual effects for the Predator's heat vision and camouflage from artists Joel Hynek, William Stout, Michael Bigelow, Robert M. Greenberg, and Robert Mrozowski are brilliant. I think Predator's are not dated at all as its eerie seeing a blurry screen and primitive blurs and lasers coming from the Predator. His sharp three red dot sights are scary and fun. The green Predator blood being the inside liquid of glow sticks is straight up genius.

Composer Alan Silvestri's bombastic score is so creative and adds layers to Predator's thrills. Silvestri writes these huge symphonic bursts for the action, while hinting at the Predator's presence with thudding drums and eerie melodies. Predator has one of the 1980's greatest film scores. You rarely hear an action-thriller with such exhilarating music that bounces between loud action rhythms and fearsome melodies for the horror sequences. Silvestri's score anticipates the Predator's appearances, really upping the ante on Predator's horror suspense.

Predator's sound design is incredibly clever from sound designers and mixers Richard L. Anderson, George H. Anderson, Gary Wright, Gene Corso, Richard Shorr, Catherine Shorr, and David E. Stone. From the Predator's clicking tones, footsteps snapping tree branches, to the whispering echoes to the voices that the Predator is replaying to lure his prey out into the open during his sick hunt. Their sound design adds to Predator's ambiance that makes 107 stretch into gripping eternity in the very best of ways.

Costume designers Marilyn Vance, James W. Tyson, and Robert B. Harris creates unearthly combat and survival gear for the Predator and mercenary and army gear for the heroes. And this is where Predator flips the script.

Written by Jim and John Thomas (Mission to Mars, Executive Decision) and directed by John McTiernan (Die Hard, Last Action Hero), this film starts as a testosterone-laced ode to American firepower and then becomes a slasher, as the team is followed by an invisible, nearly-unstoppable alien hunter (Kevin Peter Hall) who has come from space just for the sport of hunting these soldiers.

The inspiration for the film came from a joke that after Rocky IV, Stallone had run out of opponents on Earth. If they made another film, he'd have to fight an alien. Jim and John Thomas were inspired by that and wrote Hunter, which became Predator. One could argue that they had seen Without Warning, which is nearly the same idea, with an alien ‚Äî armed with futuristic weaponry and also played by Kevin Peter Hall ‚Äî on Earth to hunt humans.

Claustrophobic camera work in a dense jungle, heavily euphemistic imagery and a spectral alien make Predator an action scifi masterwork.

Having lost a chopper filled with political hot potatoes behind enemy lines, the US sends in a meathead commando unit to locate and, hopefully, extract them. Along the way, they just so happen to get caught in the crosshairs of an invisible extraterrestrial stalker, who gleefully hunts the entire team for sport.

As an adrenaline-pumping, bullet-riddled 1980s action movie (starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, no less), one can accurately predict exactly what type of cinematic experience this is. And it doesn't disappoint: we're served a buffet of idiotic one-liners, baby-oiled biceps, dismembered limbs, explosive firestorms and cute personality traits. More surprisingly, we also get a fairly effective science fiction thriller, one that's become remarkably influential in the thirty years since its premiere.

Filmed in an age before computer-rendered effects were the norm, Predator still looks convincing and impressive, especially in regards to the alien monster himself. His advanced arsenal is borderline revolutionary, a fantastic mix of high-tech and low that never quite breaks the illusion of reality, and his getup is both sleekly futuristic and functionally simple. He's a conundrum, hard to handle for a variety of reasons, which makes his lengthy final battle with Arnold (seriously did not remember how long those two went mano a mano) all the more interesting.

	Predator, starring Arnold Swarzennegger, as Major Alan "Dutch" Shaefer entered theaters in June 1987.  It blasted its way into summer theaters with a pronounced bang, grossing more than 98 million dollars worldwide. Since then, it has become one of the best sci-fi action movies of all time and is one of my favorite movies.  Predator is awesome because it upends the traditional heroes journey where the protagonist starts from nothing and ends up being the start of the show.  With Predator you get an elite paramilitary unit who is at the top of their game physically and emotionally that gets destroyed and reduced to nothing.  One by one, they are killed until just one remains.  That character, Dutch, has to recover from the utter defeat brought to him and his men, to come back and prevail over the Predator. The concept for the movie started out as a joke that the only person Rocky hadn't fought yet was E.T Thus the idea for the movie was born.  Initially being called hunter, but later dropped and changed to just Predator.  
	The human star of the show Arnold Swarzennegger was in his hay day, having recently done movies like The Terminator, Commando, and Raw Deal.  This was another movie role that no one else at the time could do justice.  He had a great supporting cast, with stars like Jessie Ventura, Carl Weathers, Elpidia Carrillio, and Shane Black.  The antagonist of the film, the Predator, played by Kevin Peter Hall does an amazing job portraying the alien on the hunt.  At a 73-minute run time, it's not the longest movie.  The pace is a fast one, with small lulls in the action that make you wait patiently for what comes next.  The movie was Filmed almost entirely on location in Mismaloya, Mexico, which provided beautiful physical locations to film.   
	The friendship and comradery of Dutch's team is something you can easily see in the film.  It lets you get really invested with each character.  They work together like a well-oiled machine.  You can see this in one of the first action scenes in the film where they initially communicate with hand and arm signals until the action kicks off.  They actually trained for months before the movie, this led to them actually preforming like a real unit.  They portray the classic expendable force used by the government to get the job done.  Case in point, they get goat roped into rescuing operation for the CIA that actually turns out to be a totally different mission.  They quickly find out that something is hunting their team and has already decimated a previous team.  After a few of them start to be killed off by the films antagonist, the Predator, they take a captive prisoner who tells them that something is hunting them for sport.  Saying it comes when its hot, and it's been very hot this summer, and that its name means who takes trophies of man.  The Predator engages in a total unfair fight at first, using its optic camouflage to remain invisible, and using its shoulder mountain plasma canon to blast through the men.  All of the team except Dutch and his captive are eventually killed.  The climax of the movie is between Dutch and the Predator.  With a frantic battle of whit and physical prowess.  If finally deems Dutch worthy to engage in a fair fight for the honor of who's stronger than who.  In the end, Dutch is the victor.  The Predator, defeated, activates a self-destruct device and removes any trace of its existence.  Dutch and his prisoner are then picked up by the CIA and the movie ends.
	Originally, concepts for the Predator had Jean-claude Van Damme portraying the role.  This didn't work out, and he was replaced by Kevin Peter Hall.  This was the best decision that could have ever been made, Van Damme's costume was akin to an orange lobster, while Stan Winston created one of the most iconic movie monsters of all time for Kevin Peter Hall to bring to life.  His performance worked was made even better by his size.  He made the main actors like Arnold look small, giving an actual sense that he could get his ass kicked by the Predator! 
	The special effects of the movie still hold up today.  The iconic thermal heat vision used by the Predator is instantly recognizable.  Equally identifiable is are the invisibility effects of the Predator's cloaking ability, as well as its now iconic glowing green blood.  The blood was made by mixing liquid from glow sticks with oil for texture.  These affects got the film a nomination for an Academy Award for Visual Effects.  The predator click noises it makes, are as recognizable as they are creepy, and the overall portrayal of the Predator is amazing.
	Snappy one liners are a plenty in the film, and lend a sometimes comical relief to another wise suspenseful tone.  A few examples are the notable, "Get to the choppaa!", or "I ain't got time to bleed," "Do you have time to duck?".  Another early exchange with Jesse Ventura's character has his asking if anyone wants some of his chew and stating," This stuff will make you a God Damn sexual Tryannosauras, just like me!".  Mid way through the movie in an attack scene on a Guerilla HQ, an enemy tries to sneak up on Dutch, and in turn gets a machete thrown into his chest, with Dutch telling him, "Stick Around!"  One liners like these were common place in the 1980's, and this movie doesn't disappoint.  Every time you watch this movie, at least one of them will get stuck in your head.  
	Predator has one of the most iconic and recognizable sound tracts that was composed by Alan Silverstri.  The music brings you into the scenes and carries you through to the end battles.  He had just come off creating music for Back to the Future.  Another notable score is the music in the beginning helicopter sequence, Little Richard's Long Tall Sally.  Every time I hear that song it makes me think of that part of the movie and Jesse Ventura's sexual Tyrannosauras comments.  It is now considered one of the best sci-fi action films of all time, and at the time of its release it was well received with audiences.  There have been countless other movies to replicate the overall story setup, but none have ever been as good as the original.  I give this movie 5 Stars out of 5 and is my all time favorite!

Predator is a scifi 80s action classic for a reason. It's fleetly paced, full to the brim with awesome, muscle bound, highly charismatic actors. Adding to that, it's got a tight script, a really cool high concept that has endured for decades, and a badass creature that is a lot more interesting than your typical mindless beast.

If someone asked you for the definition of a perfect "guy movie" than this would be the first and really only one to show. It packs every bit of a standard action/scifi thriller in, but with lots of comedy bits, memorable lines and characters, and one of the most iconic original monster designs in film history. Nothing truly comes close to being so much fun without being dumb or so much entertainment without being too hammy. 

If a person loves action movies this must certainly rank up there with the best of them. Proving that while many of these movies are nothing but cheap thrills can themselves be true forms of art.

As a child, I loved Predator. I thought it was fun, likable and efficient above other things. I revisited it again some time ago again, and was waiting for the opportunity to say that it has quickly become a favourite of mine. As far as John McTiernan's movies go, I think Die Hard is his best movie but Predator is for me definitely up there with his best. It is everything I thought it to be as a child and more.

The action is exhilarating and kept at a snappy pace with enough suspense to thrill, while the special effects are truly excellent, they are memorable, look great and enhance rather than distract. The characterisation is also good, the story is gripping, Alan Silvestri's score is terrific, the pace is snappy, McTiernan's direction is efficient and the dialogue is quotable. The acting I have no problems with either, Arnold Schwarznegger gives one of his most charismatic, efficient and likable performances here.

Overall, a great film and a classic of its decade. It may be a little too long perhaps, but it is great fun and works on all levels. 9/10 Bethany Cox
